docs.lead_paragraph: The American Red Cross will review its policy for selecting blood donors following reports that a 20-month-old baby in San Francisco may have gotten an often-fatal immune deficiency from a donor, the group's director says. However, because Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome may have a long incubation period, ''changes in donor selection or transfusion practices may not have an immediate effect on the number of new cases reported,'' Dr. Alfred Katz of Washington said in a story published here Saturday. The syndrome, found largely among male homosexuals and drug abusers, has been found in as many as 20 children, said Dr. James Oleske of New Jersey Hospital and St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark.

headline.main: Child Case Moves Red Cross To Study Blood Donor Policy
